events.text:
Made by Viridino Studios (@ViridinoStudios)

children.text: Setup the camera by moving it very high at the of the layout, creating a very cinematographic effect.
Constantly update the camera to make sure it's always behind the player, even while it's jumping.
The initial X any Y positions of a touch interaction.
Once a new touch is started, store its position for later comparisons.
Whether or not the player is allowed to perform any movement.
After the touch has ended, check which angle it's pointing towards in comparison with the previously store initial position.
If the distance between both points is long enough, perform an action based on the resulting angle. But, only if movement is allowed.
Move the player left.

actions.text: Prevent the player from preforming another movement before releasing the screen.

children.text: Move the player right.

actions.text: Prevent the player from preforming another movement before releasing the screen.

children.text: Make the player jump.

actions.text: Prevent the player from preforming another movement before releasing the screen.

children.text: Once the player has released the screen, allow it to perform other movements again.
Move the player left.
Move the player right.
Make the player jump, but only if it's not jumping already.
The direction each particle will move towards.

actions.text: How long it takes for the dust to move up and shrink is slightly randomized, resulting in a more dynamic composition.

children.text: Once the player lands on the ground, spawn a circle of dust around it.
The direction each particle will move towards.

actions.text: How long it takes for the dust to move up and shrink is slightly randomized, resulting in a more dynamic composition.
How long it takes for the dust to move up and shrink is slightly randomized, resulting in a more dynamic composition.

children.text: Spawn a trail of dust behind the player while it's moving on the ground.
An offset value (-1 and 1) is used to adjust the dust position to each one of the back tires.

actions.text: How long it takes for the dust to move up and shrink is slightly randomized, resulting in a more dynamic composition.

children.text: Move the player to another language based on the direction passed ("-1" is left and "1" is right).

actions.text: Also use the same direction parameter to update the player animation.

children.text: The direction each particle will move towards.

actions.text: How long it takes for the dust to move up and shrink is slightly randomized, resulting in a more dynamic composition.
How long it takes for the dust to move up and shrink is slightly randomized, resulting in a more dynamic composition.

children.text: Once the player is done moving, reset its animation back to the default one.
If the player isn't jumping and isn't standing on the ground, then it mean the player is falling into the void, so it's game over.
If the player isn't jumping and is overlapping a spike, then it's also game over.

events.text: Minimum distance between the player and the last created platform, before spawning a new platform.
Min and max amount of tiles per platform.
Min and max gap length between each platform.

children.text: Generate new platforms in front of the platform, so the game technically never ends.

actions.text: Move the platform up with a tween animation for a more visually interesting look.

children.text: Spawn one spike on each of the threes lanes of the platform. These will be used as obstacles for the player.
Also spawn a pillar on each side of the track, only for aesthetics reasons.
If the last created platform is far enough from the player, create a new with slightly randomized parameters, like size and position.
If the last created platform is far enough from the player, create a new with slightly randomized parameters, like size and position.
Constantly move the platforms towards the player, creating a feeling/illusion of motion.
If any of the platforms are too far away from the player, destroy them to avoid any sort of CPU/Memory overload.
Constantly scroll the clouds in the background, creating a feeling of motion.
Also make sure every billboard in the layout is facing the camera position.
How long it takes for the zeppelin to move from point A to point B.
How long it takes for the zeppelin to turn around.
Setup the zeppelin by moving it to the right side of the screen.
Once each movement is finished, start the next one in an infinite sequence.
Restart the layout while also changing all global variables back to their default values.
The direction each particle will move towards.
